title: Does quantum mechanics make free will possible? Could it allow someone to make an undetermined but not random choice? - Quora

response.answer_text: First note that the point of free will, and the only reason anyone bothers to talk about it, is that it’s whatever it happens to be that makes it moral to blame and/or punish someone for doing something bad. Unfortunately, people have had different and incompatible intuitions about what exactly that is. One tradition has been to see free will in contrast with determinism, and since quantum mechanics is non-deterministic ex hypothesis, that would seem to allow free will. However Daniel Dennett points out, I think convincingly, that what we want free will to be is much more directly opposed to reductionism. We want the person to be a moral-scenario-processing black box, with no inputs other than the moral scenario that they’re supposed to do the right thing in. We especially don’t want there to be inputs from divine intervention, or evil scientists, or duress more generally. But to fulfill the point (as outlined above), we also don’t want there to be internal workings (such as neurons or the like) that are not full moral agents. If the firing or not of some neuron is on the causal chain to pulling the lever in the Trolley problem, and it’s fated to, say, fire, because of a deterministic chain of dependencies on other neurons including those for sight/hearing/touch etc, the problem is not so much that it’s determined as that it’s taking input that is not in and of itself moral data. (The fact that a particular cone cell in the retina fired at a particular time has no moral salience in and of itself, even if it was part of a view of a runaway trolley.) So if you then allow that the neuron can also/instead take as input some irreducible randomness from quantum mechanics, you haven’t actually fixed anything, because it wasn’t moral input.

No, this is both a misunderstanding of free will, a misunderstanding of quantum mechanics and a misunderstanding of randomness. There is a very widespread error, particularly among beginner philosophers, that free will is a metaphysical question about how we make decisions, but it’s not, it’s the simple observation that we do make choices among a range of possible alternatives. Nothing else is actually required. It’s seen as more than that because it’s seen as related to questions of ethics and morality. Any undetermined decision necessarily has an element of randomness, even if it’s constrained by deterministic considerations, and it can easily be seen that reducing the randomness is equivalent to increasing the determination of the decision making process. Ultimately this line of reliance on “indeterministic” decision making means disregarding all prior considerations, including our objectives and our knowledge of the world, including things like morality. It’s a claim that we can only make moral decisions if we have no knowledge or concept of morality. Which is absurd.

Good question. There appears to be two possibilities. We determine our choices.Or our choices are determined for us.Classical physics is deterministic and the world falls into the second category. Quantum physics has interpretations some deterministic and some indeterministic where events are random in nature. The first interpretation means that our choices are determined for us the second means our choices are randomly made in both cases we are not the one's determining them and the world falls into the second category also.

I would say no. Free-will needs some amount of determinism, if only to make sense of some planning and anticipating. Then, the more you add indeterminacy, the more you threatened that free will. Quantum Mechanics does not add any free-will, but it does not demolish it either, as the probability distribution remains predictable, and we can prepare the states so that we can use them according tp our possible goal. Fee-will is just the ability to make choice in context where only partial information is available. It does not matter that a god or a super-machine can predict the choice I will make.

Quantum mechanics predicts that nature is random, not pre-determined, at the microscopic level. Nobody knows what implications this has for free will, but the prospect that humans and other animals have free will does seem significantly enhanced by quantum physics. Pre-quantum “classical physics,” by contrast, was rigidly deterministic: The present was thought to be entirely determined by past events. Thus classical physics seemed to have no room for free will. Today, this question seems much more open.

It does not. There is no room for free will in both deterministic and non-determistic universe. Quantum mechanics only tells us there will always be the factor of uncertainty even if the marcoscopic world is quite determistic. Our automated brain cells, like everything else, follow the deterministic and non-deterministic rules of nature. We can’t control how our automated brain cells react to stimulus and produce thoughts

No. Your only two options are deterministic or random. There is no mechanism for a third choice. Neither of these bestow anything that someone would identify as free will. Nor does it appear that a mixture of the two will magically produce your desired product. You’re simply out of luck. The best that can be salvaged is that we are robots marching into an uncertain future.

Does quantum mechanics make free will possible? Those know something about quantum mechanics and nothing about the human mind, those who know something about the human mind and nothing about quantum mechanics, as well as those who think they know everything about quantum mechanics and everything about the mind assert such things. Could it allow someone to make an undetermined but not random choice? No idea. JOPO. Peace! 16 May 2020

There is true probability in quantum mechanics.Probability also doesn’t give you the free will you want.Sam Harris points out that the concept of free will is not only wrong, but that it is impossible to imagine an universe in which it makes sense.It’s determinism/randomness all the way down.

You are reasoning backwards. Free will is the ability to think things over before making a choice. That human beings have free will is self-evident from everyone’s personal experience. The questions raised by philosophy and science have to begin with what is obviously true and reason from there, not begin with theories contrary to obvious truth and try to explain truth away.

It is impossible to say, because we know nothing of the workings of consciousness. We cannot even begin to produce a scientific theory of consciousness, and there is nothing in science which suggests that consciousness is even possible. While there is no knowledge of the subject area, it remains a possibility that consciousness can somehow tweak quantum processes in such a way as to select our thoughts.
A choice is by definition undetermined and the very opposite of random. We are able to make choices and it has nothing to do with quantum mechanics. You can call it free will like I do.

The problem what consciousness is is still utterly unsolved. It was unsolved before quantum mechanics. Until it is solved there is and always was the possibility of free will. Your idea may very well be correct. You are not the only one who had it. In fact, I had it myself. Tom Campell in his book My big TOE describes similar ideas.
